At-a-Glance: Map bloom calendars and fill gaps with planters, community beds, and tree advocacy. Pair with hive count discipline.
Objectives: Select gap-filling plants by season and scale.
What Good Looks Like: Street trees + planters + pocket meadows staggered by season.
Bee/wildlife-friendly species, not just honey-bee favourites.
Step-by-Step: 1) Record blooms for a year; add hive scale notes.
2) Identify gap months; shortlist species for pots/beds/trees.
3) Pitch small projects to sites; set watering/maintenance.
4) Review outcomes; adjust hive counts or plantings.
Seasonality & Climate: Heat/drought favour tough perennials and mulch.
Late frosts reset early plans—diversify species.
Data & Thresholds: Gap weeks per year; dearth weight loss rates.
Plant survival and flowering success rates.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Planter fails -> Wrong soil/water; switch species or steward.
Wasp spikes -> Move sugary plants away from entrances.
Poor public response -> Add signage and joint ownership.
Tools & Techniques: Bloom logs, community mapping, drought-proof planters.
Safety & Compliance: Permissions for planting; weight limits on roofs/balconies.
Communications: Share ‘why these plants’ and ‘who waters’ clearly.
Notes: Pick plants that please neighbours too—fragrance and tidiness matter in cities.
